newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Mch 24.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Mch 24.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

As Foreign Affairs Minister Alexander Downer refused yesterday to rule out sending Australian troops to Papua New Guinea as fears of a military takeover grow, Papua New Guinean Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan last night rejected demands for his resignation telling a television audience he will leave if the people vote him out at the next election. Page 1.

As part of a wide-ranging small business reform plan, to be announced by Prime Minister John Howard today and scheduled to start next financial year, small and medium-sized businesses with a yearly fringe benefits tax bill under A$5,000 will be exempted fom keeping Fringe Benefit Tax records. Page 1.

The Federal Government has rejected a push by the States to give the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General the right to recommend one name to the Federal Government for any High Court vacancy. Currently, High Court appointments are entirely a Commonweath responsibility but Federal Attorney-General Daryl Williams said this system had become perfunctory, and he intended to consult far more widely. Page 3.

WA, NT, Qld, SA, farmers and miners have rejected Prime Minister John Howard's proposal to continue giving Aboriginal native title holders on pastoral leases a "right to negotiate" over future mining, tourism and other developments on farms. They have laelled the Government's Wik compromise plan, put to State premiers on Friday, as unacceptable and "not negotiable", and have demanded that Aboriginal native title holders be given the same procedural rights as farmers. Page 3.
THE AUSTRALIAN

As a company of troops from the Townsville-based 3rd Brigade was on standby yesterday for immediate deployment to Papua New Guinea, senior sources rejected the possibility of Australian troops being used to intercede in the political standoff, saying they will only be used to evacuate foreign citizens in the event of bloodshed on the streets. Page 1.

The Queensland Government yesterday declared a state of natural disaster in the north of the State after Cyclone Justin, which has killed two people and caused millions of dollars worth of damage to crops, businesses and homes from Cairns to Townsville, ws upgraded by the Bureau of Meteorology from a rain depression to a category one cyclone. Page 1.

Just days before the release of the Wallis inquiry, which was established by Federal Treasurer Peter Costello last May to review the results of financial deregulation since the early 1980s and to prepare a plan for the financial sector into the next centuy, Costello has predicted credit unions will pick up new business while the big banks will be encouraged to expand globally. Page 1.

Controversial euthanasia advocate Dr Philip Nitschke, in Canberra yesterday to lobby for the Northern Territory's euthanasia law, said even if the Andrews Bill aimed at overturning the death law was passed in the Senate, he would continue to help two of hs patients who have completed the necessary documentation to die. Page 1.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

As Brigadier-General Jerry Singirok said yesterday Australian troops would not be needed to restore order in Papua New Guinea, the country's Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan last night refused to bow to Singirok's demands and resign over his controversial dcision to engage foreign mercenaries on Bougainville, saying if the people did not want him, they could vote him out of office. Page 1.

Well-known Australian author Archie Weller, who is described on the cover of his latest work, Going Home as "a pioneering Aboriginal writer", has revealed that despite for the past 20 years he has been funded, published and billed as an Aborigine, his attempts to prove his indigenous descent have failed. Page 1.

Federal Resources Minister Warwick Parer has been briefed on the discovery by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation of three huge new oilfields - near Lord Howe Island, Norfolk Island and south of Tasmania - which have the potential to double Austalia's oil reserves. Page 1.

According to documents obtained by the Herald under the Freedom of Information Act, Max Moore-Wilton, the secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, approved for himself an additional tax-free accommodation allowance of A$17,000-a-year because he, like Prime Minister John Howard, lives in Sydney. Page 2.
THE AGE

In comments which come as sacked armed forces commander Brigadier-General Jerry Singirok warned that Australia must be careful with its response to security in Papua New Guinea, the country's Prime Minister, Sir Julius Chan refused last night to resign ovr his Government's hiring of mercenaries on Bougainville, appealing for people to respect the country's Constitution and keep him in power. Page 1.

Under the Federal Government's response to the High Court's controversial Wik decision - outlined to State Premiers last Friday - native title would be wiped out in all but name, there would be a massive expansion in tax breaks for pastoralists and limits to native title claims to land where Aborigines are already living. Page 1.

Under a radical proposal prepared in response to recommendations of the Pennington drug inquiry last year and being considered by the Victorian Police, people who previously would have faced court for using or possessing small amounts of cannabis will face only a warning for the first and second offences, but any more and they would be charged. Page 1.

As the prospect of Waverley Park, the Australian Football League's current home ground, becoming redundant becomes more likely due to the deal struck between the Victorian Government and AFL over control of the proposed Docklands stadium, the AFL yesterday began considering the compensation it will probably have to negotiate with its Waverley Park tenants. Page 1.
